items.Title: [Ainslie Hewett]
items.Source: 9.5 x 7 cm. bookplate. Folder: Bookplates - Hewett, George Ainslie, in Ainslie Hewett (1880-1963) Collection, University of Louisville Margaret M. Bridwell Art Library.
items.Digital_Publisher: University of Louisville Margaret M. Bridwell Art Library
items.Description: Baby riding a fish framed by ornamental decorative elements including stars and other shapes. Below the baby and fish are the name "Ainslie Hewett" and the phrase "His Book." This bookplate was designed for the artist's first child, whose name was later legally changed to Edward Wilson Hewett. Blue ink. Signed AH with four-digit year.
items.Ordering_Information: For information about the use of these images, contact Gail Gilbert (gail.gilbert@louisville.edu), Margaret M. Bridwell Art Library (http://louisville.edu/library/art/ ), University of Louisville.
items.Creator: Hewett, Ainslie, 1880-1963 (bookplate designer),
items.Citation_Information: See http://digital.library.louisville.edu/collections/hewett/about.php#conditions for guidance on citing this item. To cite the digital version, add its Reference URL (found by following the link in the gray header above the digital file).
Subject: Bookplates
Labels

items.Title: [Alfred "Boy" Burns and family]
items.Source: 3 x 5.5 in. b&w photographic print. Item no. 1982.01.391.p in the Claude C. Matlack Collection, University of Louisville Photographic Archives.
items.Description: Alfred "Boy" Burns and his family pose in front of their cabin. From left to right are: Gracie, Roy, an unidentified child sitting in the lap of Alfred's second wife Vinia "Aunt Viny" Robinson, Atkins or "Smokey" and Alfred Burns. Their dog stands in the door of the cabin behind them. "Aunt Viny" was a shoe cobbler and "Boy" was a fiddler. Handwritten on bottom border: 391. See ULPA 1982.01.522.p for another image of this family.
items.People_Pictured: Burns, Alfred, Burns, Atkins, Burns, Gracie, Burns, Roy, Burns, Vinia Robinson, 1875-1962,
items.Appears_In_Publications: Thomas, Samuel W., ed. Dawn comes to the mountains. Louisville, Ky.: George Rogers Clark Press, 1981, p. 96.
items.Ordering_Information: To order a reproduction, inquire about permissions, or for information about prices see: http://louisville.edu/library/ekstrom/special/fees.html; please cite the Image Number when ordering.

items.Title: Anna and Will Harris and Jean Thomas at McGuffey Log School.
items.Source: 2 1/2 x 4 1/4 in. b&w nitrate negative. Item no. 1979.33.0709 in the Jean Thomas, The Traipsin' Woman, Collection, University of Louisville Photographic Archives.
items.Collection: Jean Thomas, The Traipsin' Woman, Collection,
items.Description: Will Harris, Jean Thomas, and Anna Harris, all dressed in white, stand on the steps of the McGuffey Log School. Thomas acquired possession of this schoolhouse (similar to the one she had attended as a child) in Big Sandy country, and had it moved to the land adjacent to her 'Wee House in the Wood,' where it was dedicated on May 16, 1937 as a shrine to McGuffey. She left the door open for visitors, and created Friday afternoon performances (sometimes aired on a local radio station) with 1890s period costumes, furnishings, and lessons from McGuffey Readers.
items.People_Pictured: Harris, Anna, Harris, Will, Thomas, Jean, b. 1881,
items.Ordering_Information: To order a reproduction, inquire about permissions, or for information about prices see: http://louisville.edu/library/ekstrom/special/fees.html; please cite the Image Number when ordering.

Thomas acquired possession of this schoolhouse (similar to the one she had attended as a child) in Big Sandy country, and had it moved to the land adjacent to her 'Wee House in the Wood,' where it was dedicated on May 16, 1937 as a shrine to McGuffey. She left the door open for visitors, and created Friday afternoon performances (sometimes aired on a local radio station) with 1890s period costumes, furnishings, and lessons from McGuffey Readers.

items.Description: Dr. Annie S. Veech of Louisville, Kentucky, wearing a long coat, gloves, and a brimmed hat. The photograph has remnants of the newspaper article attached to the top edge, small cracks along the surface, and a yellow discoloration from age. Handwritten on back of image: April 1936, on Grace liner, Santa Barbara, director of the bureau of, National & Child Health, of the State Board of Health. Stamped on back: April 17, 1936.

items.Related_Images: Physical collection includes 3 x 5 in. b&w negative (Item no. ULPA 1982.01.032.n).
items.Title: Boing [sic] to the grist mill.
items.Source: 3 x 5.5 in. b&w photographic print. Item no. 1982.01.032.p in the Claude C. Matlack Collection, University of Louisville Photographic Archives.
items.Description: A woman and a small boy ride a horse or mule to the gristmill. The child has a "turn" or sackful of corn in his lap. The woman wears a bonnet and rides in typical sidesaddle fashion while the boy straddles the horse or mule as they ride away from the camera. This digital collection also includes an original print of this negative where the background has been cropped (Item no. ULPA 1982.01.554.p).
items.Appears_In_Publications: Thomas, Samuel W., ed. Dawn comes to the mountains. Louisville, Ky.: George Rogers Clark Press, 1981, p. 128; Richardson, Darrell C. Mountain rising: The story of James Anderson Burns and Oneida Institute. Oneida, Ky.: Oneida Mountaineer Press, 1986.

items.Location_Depicted: Cherokee Park (Louisville, Ky.), Louisville (Ky.), Jefferson County (Ky.),
items.Description: Back view of Casa Mia, house of Alexander P. Witty on Red Fox Road in Cherokee Park, Louisville, Kentucky. A small child in white sits with a small dog at the top of stepstones leading up the two level yard. They are partly sheltered by a tree. At the base of the small stairway are tulips. The back of the house is two-story concrete with a one and a half story open air wing at right and a perpendicular one story wing at left which has large, dark, square crisscross patterns and one window.
items.Title: [Casa Mia, Louisville, Kentucky, 1929]
